elements.content: Three unique [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core-based magnetic complexes, [Cu4(amtrz)2(μ3-OH)2(nb)6]·2H2O (1), {[Cu5(H2O)6(trz)2(μ3-OH)2(btc)2]·0.6H2O} n (2), and {[Cu5(H2O)2(Htrz)2(μ3-OH)2(btec)2]·0.125H2O} n (3) (amtrz = 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole, Htrz = 1,2,4-triazole, Hnb = 4-nitrobenzoic acid, H3btc = 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid, and H4btec = 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid), were synthesized by varying the spacer functionality of the mixed ligands. Significantly resulting from the cooperative cocoordination of the metal ions with polytopic triazolyl and carboxylate groups, a structural transformation from a discrete CuII 4 cluster for 1 to two alternate CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based three-dimensional frameworks for 2 and 3 was achieved. Moreover, the connectivity manner of the structural subunits in 2 and 3 depends strongly on the number and position of the carboxylate group attached on the phenyl backbone. The nearest-neighbor interactions within the CuII 4 cluster and between CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core mediated by the mixed short bridges were quantitatively calculated and compared based on the established magneto-structural relationships. Strong antiferromagnetic coupling interactions up to −206(4) cm–1 were observed in the isolated CuII 4 cluster due to the favorable spatial orientation of the mixed multiple heterobridges toward the spin carriers.

elements.content: Polynuclear metal cluster-based magnetic complexes have recently attracted intense interest due to their significance in interpretation of the underlying magneto-structural correlations as well as their new developments in nanomagnetic and photoresponsive fields. Undoubtedly, a synthetic challenge involves discovering simple and efficient methods to aggregate two or more paramagnetic metal ions into a small, single molecular entity by short bridging ligands either from chemical synthesis or from the commercially available chemicals. In this regard, a combination of simple and facile ligands with multiple tunable bridging groups that can hold several spin carriers in a polynuclear system through a network of bridges becomes one of the promising strategies, although such mixed ligands are comparatively restricted. In previous investigations, we have found that the self-assembly of heterocyclic triazolyl and three-atom carboxylate groups could synergically aggregate four or seven spin carriers into a dense cluster under hydrothermal conditions. Instead, the phenyl tether modified by a variable number of carboxylate groups can behave as a polytopic connector to essentially extend the local clusters into versatile high-dimensional frameworks. On the other hand, the cooperative superexchange interactions mediated by multiple heterobridges within the local cluster can lead to unusual long-range ferromagnetic ordering, interesting spin-canting, spin-frustration, and strong antiferromagnetism. As an extension along this line, herein, we focus on the connectivity manner and magnetic superexchange coupling of the polynuclear cluster by varying the spacer functionality of the mixed ligands. Thus, three aromatic coligands with different numbers of carboxylic groups, 4-nitrobenzoic acid (Hnb), 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc), and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4btec), were selected to self-assemble with an isotropic CuII ion and triazolyl-containing ligands (4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (amtrz) and 1,2,4-triazole (Htrz)). As a result, three novel [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core-based magnetic samples, one discrete CuII 4 cluster for 1 and two alternate CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with different connectivity for 2 and 3, were respectively obtained. Apparently, such a structural modulation is achieved by changing the number/position of the carboxylate group toward the phenyl ring as well as the competitive binding between the triazolyl and the carboxylate group. Additionally, unusual strong antiferromagnetic couplings up to −206(4) cm–1 in the discrete CuII 4 cluster are observed, which are closely related to the favorable orientation of the mixed heterobridges toward the spin carrier.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polynuclear metal cluster-based magnetic complexes have recently attracted intense interest due to their significance in interpretation of the underlying magneto-structural correlations as well as their new developments in nanomagnetic and photoresponsive fields. Undoubtedly, a synthetic challenge involves discovering simple and efficient methods to aggregate two or more paramagnetic metal ions into a small, single molecular entity by short bridging ligands either from chemical synthesis or from the commercially available chemicals. In this regard, a combination of simple and facile ligands with multiple tunable bridging groups that can hold several spin carriers in a polynuclear system through a network of bridges becomes one of the promising strategies, although such mixed ligands are comparatively restricted. In previous investigations, we have found that the self-assembly of heterocyclic triazolyl and three-atom carboxylate groups could synergically aggregate four or seven spin carriers into a dense cluster under hydrothermal conditions. Instead, the phenyl tether modified by a variable number of carboxylate groups can behave as a polytopic connector to essentially extend the local clusters into versatile high-dimensional frameworks. On the other hand, the cooperative superexchange interactions mediated by multiple heterobridges within the local cluster can lead to unusual long-range ferromagnetic ordering, interesting spin-canting, spin-frustration, and strong antiferromagnetism. As an extension along this line, herein, we focus on the connectivity manner and magnetic superexchange coupling of the polynuclear cluster by varying the spacer functionality of the mixed ligands. Thus, three aromatic coligands with different numbers of carboxylic groups, 4-nitrobenzoic acid (Hnb), 1,2,3-benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3btc), and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4btec), were selected to self-assemble with an isotropic CuII ion and triazolyl-containing ligands (4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (amtrz) and 1,2,4-triazole (Htrz)). As a result, three novel [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core-based magnetic samples, one discrete CuII 4 cluster for 1 and two alternate CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based three-dimensional (3D) frameworks with different connectivity for 2 and 3, were respectively obtained. Apparently, such a structural modulation is achieved by changing the number/position of the carboxylate group toward the phenyl ring as well as the competitive binding between the triazolyl and the carboxylate group. Additionally, unusual strong antiferromagnetic couplings up to -206(4) cm-1 in the discrete CuII 4 cluster are observed, which are closely related to the favorable orientation of the mixed heterobridges toward the spin carrier.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially purchased (amtrz, Htrz, Hnb, H3btc, and H4btec were from Acros and other analytical-grade reagents were from Tianjin Chemical Reagent Factory) and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out with a CE-440 (Leeman-Laboratories) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer in the range 4000–400 cm–1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on a Shimadzu simultaneous DTG-60A compositional analysis instrument from room temperature to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained from a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 0.1 s/step and a step size of 0.01° in 2θ. The simulated PXRD pattern was calculated using single-crystal X-ray diffraction data and processed by the free Mercury v1.4 program downloaded from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. Magnetic susceptibilities were acquired on a Quantum Design (SQUID) magnetometer MPMS-XL-7 with polycrystalline samples, in which the phase purity of the samples was determined by PXRD experiments. The data were corrected for TIP and the diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants. An experimental correction for the sample holder was also applied.

Experimental Section

Materials and Instruments

All chemicals were commercially purchased (amtrz, Htrz, Hnb, H3btc, and H4btec were from Acros and other analytical-grade reagents were from Tianjin Chemical Reagent Factory) and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out with a CE-440 (Leeman-Laboratories) analyzer. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on an Avatar-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer in the range 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) experiments were performed on a Shimadzu simultaneous DTG-60A compositional analysis instrument from room temperature to 800 °C under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained from a Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA for Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), with a scan speed of 0.1 s/step and a step size of 0.01° in 2θ. The simulated PXRD pattern was calculated using single-crystal X-ray diffraction data and processed by the free Mercury v1.4 program downloaded from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center. Magnetic susceptibilities were acquired on a Quantum Design (SQUID) magnetometer MPMS-XL-7 with polycrystalline samples, in which the phase purity of the samples was determined by PXRD experiments. The data were corrected for TIP and the diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal's constants. An experimental correction for the sample holder was also applied.

elements.content: To a mixed methanol–water solution (1:1, 10.0 mL) containing amtrz (25.2 mg, 0.3 mmol) and Hnb (33.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) was slowly added an aqueous solution of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (48.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) with constant stirring. The pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 6.0 by triethylamine. The resulting mixture was further stirred for another one hour at room temperature and filtered. Blue block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained by slow evaporation of the filtrate at room temperature in five days. Yield: 40% based on Hnb. Anal. elements.content: A mixture of Htrz (14.0 mg, 0.2 mmol), H3btc (22.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and CuCl2·2H2O (34.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was dissolved in doubly deionized water (10.0 mL), and the initial pH value of the mixture was adjusted to ca. 6.0 by triethylamine. The mixture was then transferred into a parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23.0 mL) and heated to 160 °C for 72 h under autogenous pressure. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 2.1 °C·h–1, blue block-shaped crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly, washed with water, and dried in air (Yield: 40% based on CuII). Anal. Calcd for C22H25.2Cu5N6O20.6: C, 25.88; H, 2.49; N, 8.23%. Found: C, 25.73; H, 2.58; N, 8.19%. elements.content:
Perchlorate salts of transition-metal complexes are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be prepared and handled with caution.

X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities for 1–3 were collected on a Bruker APEX–II CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation with a radiation wavelength of 0.71073 Å by using the φ–ω scan technique at 296(2) K for 1 and 2 and at 150(2) K for 3. There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Semiempirical multiscan absorption corrections were applied by SADABS, and the program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. The H atoms of the water molecule were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. The lattice water molecule in 2 and 3 is disordered with the site occupancy of 0.30 and 0.125, respectively. The bound water molecule of Cu3 site in 2 was disordered between two positions (O10 and O10′) with the equal site occupancy. The distances of Cu3–O10 and Cu3–O10′ were restrained to 2.77 and 2.55 Å, respectively. The thermal parameters for O10, O10′, and O11 atoms were refined with isotropy. The crystallographic data and the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Tables –, respectively. CCDC - 839224 (1), 839225 (2), and 839226 (3) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The reaction of inorganic CuII salt with Hnb and amtrz in mixed methanol–water medium at room temperature allowed the formation of 1. In contrast, both 2 and 3 with mixed Htrz and different aromatic polycarboxylate ligands were directly isolated at high temperature under hydrothermal reactions. Because of the different numbers of carboxylic groups attached on the phenyl ring, special attention has been paid to the pH control of the reaction mixture. In the IR spectra, a broad band beyond 3261 cm–1 confirmed the existence of a hydroxyl group and/or water molecule in 1–3. The weak bands located at 3423, 3319, and 3166 cm–1 in 1 corresponded to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of N–H, indicating the occurrence of the exocyclic amino group of the amtrz ligand in 1. Additionally, compared with the free aromatic acid, the absence of a band at ca. 1694 cm–1 for 1, 1733 cm–1 for 2, and 1708 cm–1 for 3 implied the full deprotonation of Hnb, H3btc, and H4btec in 1–3. The characteristic multiple bands for the asymmetric (νas) and symmetric (νs) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group were observed between 1600 and 1400 cm–1, and their different separations (Δν = νas – νs) suggested the various coordination modes of the carboxylate groups. Thus, the IR results of 1–3 were in good agreement with those from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data.

Results and Discussion

Syntheses and IR Spectra

The reaction of inorganic CuII salt with Hnb and amtrz in mixed methanol-water medium at room temperature allowed the formation of 1. In contrast, both 2 and 3 with mixed Htrz and different aromatic polycarboxylate ligands were directly isolated at high temperature under hydrothermal reactions. Because of the different numbers of carboxylic groups attached on the phenyl ring, special attention has been paid to the pH control of the reaction mixture. In the IR spectra, a broad band beyond 3261 cm-1 confirmed the existence of a hydroxyl group and/or water molecule in 1-3. The weak bands located at 3423, 3319, and 3166 cm-1 in 1 corresponded to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of N-H, indicating the occurrence of the exocyclic amino group of the amtrz ligand in 1. Additionally, compared with the free aromatic acid, the absence of a band at ca. 1694 cm-1 for 1, 1733 cm-1 for 2, and 1708 cm-1 for 3 implied the full deprotonation of Hnb, H3btc, and H4btec in 1-3. The characteristic multiple bands for the asymmetric (νas) and symmetric (νs) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group were observed between 1600 and 1400 cm-1, and their different separations (Δν = νas - νs) suggested the various coordination modes of the carboxylate groups. Thus, the IR results of 1-3 were in good agreement with those from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data.

elements.content: Structural determination reveals that 1 is a discrete tetranuclear cluster with an inversion center, which is infinitely extended into a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular layer by O–H···O and N–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions. As shown in Figure a, the CuII 4 cluster of 1 is constructed from two crystallographically asymmetric units, consisting of four CuII ions, a pair of μ3-OH groups, two neutral amtrz ligands, and six fully deprotonated nb– anions. Both unique CuII ions (Cu1 and Cu2) are in the NO4 donor sets, displaying slightly distorted square-pyramidal geometries with Addison parameter τ (Addison parameter is defined as an index of trigonality) = 0.05 for Cu1 and τ = 0.13 for Cu2. The basal planes of the two metal ions are well-defined by one endocyclic N atom from one neutral amtrz ligand and three O donors from one μ3-OH group and two separate carboxylate groups from two nb– anions. One O atom from the carboxylate group of the third crystallographically independent nb– anion and from the μ3-OH group occupies the apical position of Cu1 and Cu2 ions, respectively. The apical Cu–O distance is nearly 0.5 Å longer than those of basal Cu–O/Cu–N bond lengths (Table ). Notably, two adjacent basal planes that contain two adjacent asymmetric CuII atoms form a dihedral angle of 14.91°.

Crystal Structures of 1-3. [Cu4(amtrz)2(μ3-OH)2(nb)6]⋅2H2O (1)

Structural determination reveals that 1 is a discrete tetranuclear cluster with an inversion center, which is infinitely extended into a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular layer by O-H⋅⋅⋅O and N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen-bonding interactions. As shown in Figure a, the CuII 4 cluster of 1 is constructed from two crystallographically asymmetric units, consisting of four CuII ions, a pair of μ3-OH groups, two neutral amtrz ligands, and six fully deprotonated nb- anions. Both unique CuII ions (Cu1 and Cu2) are in the NO4 donor sets, displaying slightly distorted square-pyramidal geometries with Addison parameter τ (Addison parameter is defined as an index of trigonality) = 0.05 for Cu1 and τ = 0.13 for Cu2. The basal planes of the two metal ions are well-defined by one endocyclic N atom from one neutral amtrz ligand and three O donors from one μ3-OH group and two separate carboxylate groups from two nb- anions. One O atom from the carboxylate group of the third crystallographically independent nb- anion and from the μ3-OH group occupies the apical position of Cu1 and Cu2 ions, respectively. The apical Cu-O distance is nearly 0.5 Å longer than those of basal Cu-O/Cu-N bond lengths (Table ). Notably, two adjacent basal planes that contain two adjacent asymmetric CuII atoms form a dihedral angle of 14.91°.

elements.content: Acting as a asymmetric tridentate bridge, a pair of μ3-OH groups aggregate four CuII ions from two adjacent asymmetric units, generating a butterfly shaped [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core. The intermetallic distance by the μ3-OH group is 3.1536(2), 3.3954(2), and 3.2012(2) Å for Cu1···Cu2, Cu1···Cu2A, and Cu2···Cu2A, respectively. The Cu–O–Cu angle is 122.58(1) °, 94.40(8)°, and 96.39(4)° for Cu1–O13–Cu2A, Cu1–O13–Cu2, and Cu2–O13–Cu2A, respectively. Analogous [Co4(μ3-OH)2]6+ motif can also be found in paramagnetic CoII-containing coordination polymers. The cationic [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core in 1 is further strengthened by two symmetry-related bridging μ2-N1,N2-amtrz ligands and two pairs of carboxylate groups from two unique nb– anions in single-atom (μ2-η2:η0-COO–) and bidentate bridging modes (syn, syn-μ2-η1:η1-COO–). Obviously, four different heterobridges (μ2-N1,N2-amtrz, μ3–OH, syn, syn-μ2-η1:η1-COO–, and μ2-η2:η0-COO–) are observed in the overall CuII 4 cluster of 1, which are hopefully expected to mediate interesting magnetic couplings.

elements.content: By increasing the number of the carboxylate groups attached on the phenyl backbone, an extended 3D framework of 2 with a (43·52·67·7·82)­(53·62·8)­(4·52)2 topological symbol is obtained, which is constructed from a unique CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain and anionic btc3– linker. As shown in Figure a, the coordination environment of Cu1 and the coordination sphere of Cu2 in the local CuII 4 cluster of 2 differ obviously from those of 1. Although the square-pyramidal Cu1 ion (τ = 0.12) in 2 is also in a NO4 donor set, two terminal aqua ligands around the Cu1 in 2 replace the monodentate carboxylate group in the basal plane and the apical single-atom carboxylate bridge of Cu1 in 1. Thus, the number of superexchange pathways between Cu1 and Cu2 in 2 is decreased due to the replacement of the apical μ2-η2:η0-COO– mediator by the terminal aqua ligand. The Cu2 ion in 2 is in a severely distorted trigonal–bipyramidal arrangement with τ = 0.70, not in a square–pyramidal arrangement. The additional Cu3 site in 2 is in an elongated octahedron with the equatorial plane formed by pairs of heterocyclic N and carboxylate O donors from pairs of μ3-trz and btc3– ligands. The two axial positions are blocked by two aqua ligands with the axial Cu–O distance longer than those of equatorial Cu–O and Cu–N bonds (see Table ).

elements.content: Similar to 1, two μ3-OH groups tightly hold four CuII atoms into a [Cu4(μ3-OH)2]6+ core with the intermetallic distances of 3.4063(6), 2.9470(6), and 3.4020(6) Å for Cu1···Cu2A, Cu2···Cu2A, and Cu1···Cu2, respectively. Interestingly, the CuII 4 clusters in 2 are alternating with the octahedral CuII 1 cores through a μ3-trz ligand, affording an infinite one-dimensional (1D) wavy chain running along [0 1 1̅] (Figure b). The CuII···CuII distances across the μ3-trz connector are 6.01175 and 5.9857(5) Å, which is much longer than those in the CuII 4 cluster. Previously, only two types of low-dimensional chains consisting of CuII 4 + CuII 1 and CuII 3 + CuII 2 motifs were constructed from different combination of mixed ligands. Furthermore, each 1D CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain of 2 is periodically interlinked with its six neighbors through six crystallographically equivalent btc3– ligands, leading to an unusual 3D coordination framework of 2 (Figure c). Each CuII 4 core in 2 is surrounded by four btc3– and two μ3-trz ligands, and can be topologically considered as a 6-connected node. The octahedrally coordinated CuII 1 core is surrounded by pairs of btc3– and μ3-trz ligands, and thus can be treated as a 4-connected node. In contrast, each anionic btc3– linker is connected with two CuII 4 cores and one CuII 1 core, and can be regarded as a 3-connected node (Figure S2 in ). Therefore, 2 can be simplified into a 3,4,6-trinodal network with a Schläfli notation of (43·52·67·7·82)­(53·62·8)­(4·52)2 (Figure d).

elements.content: Complex 3 also exhibits a CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-derived 3D framework with a (44·62)2(46·64)4(48·66·8)3 topological notation. Notably, the connectivity of CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core in 3 differs from that of 2. As shown in Figure a, the additional cocoordination of aqua ligand makes the Cu1 site of 3 in a distorted octahedron, apparently different from the square-pyramidal Cu1 ion in 1 and 2. Interestingly, rather than being in an elongated octahedron in 2, the Cu3 site in 3 exhibits slightly irregular planar-square geometry chelated by two pairs of carboxylate O donors from four symmetry-related btec4– ligands. The axial Cu–O distances of the CuII ions are generally 0.5 Å longer than those of Cu–O/Cu–N separations in the basal plane (Table ).

elements.content: To compare the different connectivity of CuII 4 cluster, CuII 1 core, and organic linkers between 2 and 3, the overall framework of 3 can also be topologically analyzed. Each CuII 4 cluster and planar-square CuII 1 core in 3 are respectively surrounded by six and four btec4– ligands, and thus can be considered as 6- and 4-connected nodes. In contrast, each anionic btec4– linker is connected with three CuII 4 clusters and two CuII 1 cores, and can be treated as a 5-connected node (Figure S3 in ). Therefore, the complicated 3D framework of 3 can be simplified into a 4,5,6-trinodal network with a Schläfli notation (44·62)2(46·64)4(48·66·8)3 (Figure d).

elements.content: TG experiments were carried out to explore the thermal stability of 1–3 (Figure S4 in ). As a result, both 1 and 2 exhibited two obvious weight-loss processes. The first stage was observed between 68 and 124 °C for 1 (obsd. 1.6%, calcd. 2.4%) and between 57 and 95 °C for 2 (calcd. 11.6%, obsd. 10.1%), corresponding to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules. The second one was from 228 to 458 °C for 1 and from 285 to 499 °C for 2, which should be ascribed to the decomposition of the mixed ligands and the collapse of the CuII 4 cluster. In contrast, only one weight-loss stage occurred between 290 and 472 °C for 3, corresponding to the cooperative decomposition of the 3D robust framework. The final residue of the three complexes was all calculated to be CuO (expt. 23.0%, calcd. 21.4% for 1; obsd. 38.3%, calcd. 39.0% for 2; calcd. 38.7%, obsd. 39.5% for 3). The phase purity and structural consistency of the bulk samples of 1–3 have also been evidenced by the comparisons of the experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns (Figure S5 in ).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and PXRD

TG experiments were carried out to explore the thermal stability of 1-3 (Figure S4 in ). As a result, both 1 and 2 exhibited two obvious weight-loss processes. The first stage was observed between 68 and 124 °C for 1 (obsd. 1.6%, calcd. 2.4%) and between 57 and 95 °C for 2 (calcd. 11.6%, obsd. 10.1%), corresponding to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules. The second one was from 228 to 458 °C for 1 and from 285 to 499 °C for 2, which should be ascribed to the decomposition of the mixed ligands and the collapse of the CuII 4 cluster. In contrast, only one weight-loss stage occurred between 290 and 472 °C for 3, corresponding to the cooperative decomposition of the 3D robust framework. The final residue of the three complexes was all calculated to be CuO (expt. 23.0%, calcd. 21.4% for 1; obsd. 38.3%, calcd. 39.0% for 2; calcd. 38.7%, obsd. 39.5% for 3). The phase purity and structural consistency of the bulk samples of 1-3 have also been evidenced by the comparisons of the experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns (Figure S5 in ).

elements.content: The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on the polycrystalline samples of 1 –3 under an applied direct-current (dc) field of 2 kOe. The χM T value of 1 is 0.55 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K (Figure a) and is much lower than the spin-only value (1.50 cm3 K mol–1) for four magnetically uncoupled CuII ions with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0, suggesting very strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the CuII ions even at room temperature. Upon cooling, the χM T value sharply decreased down to 0.01 cm3 K mol–1 at 75 K and remained almost constant until 2 K. The abrupt increase of the χM below 75 K is due to the presence of paramagnetic impurities. Structurally, due to the presence of a couple of asymmetric μ3-OH bridges within the Cu4 II cluster, three exchange integrals, J 1, J 2, and J 3, are required to quantitatively describe each pairwise superexchange interaction between the adjacent CuII ions (Figure inset). The spin Hamiltonian, H = −2J 1( S 1· S 2 + S 1A· S 2A) – 2J 2 S 1· S 1A – 2J 3( S 1· S 2A + S 1A· S 2), is used to fit the experimental magnetic data of 1, in which S 1, S 2, S 1A, and S 2A are the spin operators of Cu1, Cu2, Cu1A, and Cu2A, respectively. The best-fit parameters obtained by the MAGPACK suite are g = 2.15(1), J 1 = −206(4) cm–1, J 2 = 3.2(3) cm–1, J 3 = −21.4(3) cm–1, and ρ (the percentage of paramagnetic impurity) = 0.015(1), with R = 3.4 × 10–4, where R is the agreement factor defined as Σ­[(χM T)obsd – (χM T)calcd]2/Σ­(χM T)2 obsd.

Magnetic Properties

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on the polycrystalline samples of 1 -3 under an applied direct-current (dc) field of 2 kOe. The χM T value of 1 is 0.55 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K (Figure a) and is much lower than the spin-only value (1.50 cm3 K mol-1) for four magnetically uncoupled CuII ions with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0, suggesting very strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the CuII ions even at room temperature. Upon cooling, the χM T value sharply decreased down to 0.01 cm3 K mol-1 at 75 K and remained almost constant until 2 K. The abrupt increase of the χM below 75 K is due to the presence of paramagnetic impurities. Structurally, due to the presence of a couple of asymmetric μ3-OH bridges within the Cu4 II cluster, three exchange integrals, J 1, J 2, and J 3, are required to quantitatively describe each pairwise superexchange interaction between the adjacent CuII ions (Figure  inset). The spin Hamiltonian,  H  = -2J 1( S  1⋅ S  2 +  S  1A⋅ S  2A) - 2J 2  S  1⋅ S  1A - 2J 3( S  1⋅ S  2A +  S  1A⋅ S  2), is used to fit the experimental magnetic data of 1, in which S 1, S 2, S 1A, and S 2A are the spin operators of Cu1, Cu2, Cu1A, and Cu2A, respectively. The best-fit parameters obtained by the MAGPACK suite are g = 2.15(1), J 1 = -206(4) cm-1, J 2 = 3.2(3) cm-1, J 3 = -21.4(3) cm-1, and ρ (the percentage of paramagnetic impurity) = 0.015(1), with R = 3.4 × 10-4, where R is the agreement factor defined as Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd.

elements.content: The superexchange couplings of 1 strongly depends on the mixed 4-fold heterobridges within the discrete CuII 4 cluster (μ3-OH, μ2-amtrz, syn, syn-μ2-η1:η1-COO–, and μ2-η2:η0-COO–) based on the structural analysis above. The strongest antiferromagnetic coupling for J 1 should be ascribed to the superexchange pathways involving the double μ3-OH and μ2-amtrz mediators, because they both are located in the basal positions of the Cu1 and Cu2. Moreover, the bigger bond angles of Cu–N–N (120.834(7)o and 120.540(5)o) and Cu1–O13–Cu2A (122.58(1)o) can further increase the overlap between the magnetic orbital of the CuII ion and the σ-orbitals of the endocyclic N atom/hydroxyl group to enhance the antiferromagnetic interaction. In contrast, the poor overlap between the orbitals of the Cu2 and Cu2A centers through two apical μ3-OH homobridges, together with a smaller bond angle of Cu2–O13–Cu2A (<97.5o), transfers a small ferromagnetic coupling corresponding to J 2. The moderate antiferromagnetic J 3 is associated with the triple heterobridges (μ2-η2:η0-COO–, syn, syn-μ2-η1:η1-COO–, and μ3-OH). On the basis of the bond angles of Cu1–O13–Cu2 (94.40(8)o) and Cu1–O5–Cu2 (91.04(6)o), the superexchange pathways by double μ3-OH and μ2-η2:η0-COO– bridges transfer a weak ferromagnetic coupling, which is overcompensated by strong antiferromagnetic coupling mediating by the syn, syn-μ2-η1:η1-COO– bridge and essentially contributes to a negative coupling constant of J 3. Thus, the superexchange interactions are well related with the different multiple pathways between the paramagnetic centers.

elements.content: The magnetic interactions of the high-dimensional frameworks of 2 and 3 occur essentially in the alternating CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain due to the longer interchain CuII···CuII separations. Interestingly, the difference in magnetic phenomena exhibited by 2 and 3 appears to result from the specific connectivity of CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core. As shown in Figure b, the χM T value per Cu5 unit of 2 is 1.94 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K. Upon cooling, the χM T product of 2 rapidly decreases to a value of 0.45 cm3 K mol–1 at 16 K resulting from the strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the CuII spins. Then, due to the interchain weak antiferromagnetic interactions, the χM T value drops slowly to 0.36 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. The χM T value per Cu5 unit of 3 at 300 K (1.52 cm3 K mol–1) is smaller than that of 2, suggesting relatively stronger antiferromagnetic interactions between the CuII ions in 3. With the decreasing temperature, the χM T product of 3 decreases first to the value of 0.434 cm3 K mol–1 at 5.0 K, and then slowly increases to the value of 0.48 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K. The decay of χM T above 5.0 K indicates strong antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the CuII ions. The decrease of χM T down to about 0.43 – 0.45 cm3 K mol–1 just indicates that only the S = 1/2 ground state of the pentamer in 2 and 3 is populated. The slight increase of χM T between 5.0 and 2.0 K in 3 suggests the possibly weak interchain ferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: Because of the different connectivity between the CuII 4 cluster and the CuII 1 core (one μ3-trz ligand for 2 and double μ2-η2:η0-COO– and cis-butenedicarboxylate heterobridges for 3), two different spin Hamiltonian forms with H = −2J 1( S 1· S 2 + S 1A· S 2A) – 2J 2 S 1· S 1A – 2J 3( S 1· S 2A + S 1A· S 2) – 2J 4( S 1· S 3 + S 2· S 3) for 2 and H = −2J 1( S 1· S 2 + S 1A· S 2A) – 2J 2 S 1· S 1A – 2J 3( S 1· S 2A + S 1A· S 2) – 2J 4 S 1· S 3 for 3 are used to describe the magnetic interactions. J 1, J 2, and J 3 are corresponding to the coupling constants between the adjacent CuII ions in the CuII 4 cluster, and the additional J 4 is to describe the magnetic exchange between the CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core (Figure inset). Additionally, the interpentamer magnetic interaction (zJ′) can be further considered by molecular field approximation. Thus, the equation χM = χCu5/(1 – 2zJ′/Ng 2β2) is used to fit the experimental magnetic data of the two complexes. The best-fit parameters using the MAGPACK suite are g = 2.13(2), J 1 = −87.4(6) cm–1, J 2 = 13.3(3) cm–1, J 3 = −43.2(5) cm–1, J 4 = −17.4(3) cm–1 and zJ′ = −48.1(4) cm–1 with R = 3.2 × 10–4 for 2, and g = 2.14(2), J 1 = −141(3) cm–1, J 2 = 17.2(2) cm–1, J 3 = −26.8(4) cm–1, J 4 = −1.2(1) cm–1 and zJ′ = −5.7(2) cm–1, with R = 1.1 × 10–4 for 3. Apparently, the three coupling constants within the CuII 4 cluster of 2 and 3 are comparable to those transferred by mixed μ2-amtrz, μ2-COO–, and μ3-OH heterobridges in 1, and their difference depends strongly on the specific spatial orientation of the heterobridges. Notably, the bigger Cu–O–Cu angle of 2 (118.703(2)o for Cu1–O7–Cu2) than 3 (94.413(1)o for Cu1–O9–Cu2) essentially gives rise to the stronger antiferromagnetic coupling (J 3) between Cu1 and Cu2 ions. The superexchange magnetic interaction (J 4) between CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core for 2 and 3 indicates that the antiferromagnetic interaction transmitted by μ3-triazolyl group is moderately stronger than that of μ2-η2:η0-COO– bridge, confidently confirming our previous hypothesis in the magnetic data treatment of [Cu5(amtrz)2(H2O)2(μ3-OH)2(btec)2] n . On the basis of the molecular field approximation, the different zJ′ values of 2 and 3 mainly reflect the cooperating contribution of the multiple mediators (two μ3-amtrz mediators for 2 and mixed μ2-η2:η0-COO– and cis-butenedicarboxylate heterobridges for 3) to the interpentamer superexchange interactions as well as the weak interchain ferromagnetic interactions for 3. The strongest antiferromagnetic coupling constant of 1 is greatly increased by 59.1 cm–1 compared with the reported CuII 4 cluster-based complexes, which are strongly related with the specific spatial orientations of the mediators toward the spin carriers.

elements.content: A structural change from one discrete CuII 4 cluster to two polymeric CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based 3D frameworks with (43·52·67·7·82)­(53·62·8)­(4·52)2 and (44·62)2(46·64)4(48·66·8)3 Schläfli notations was achieved by varying the spacer functionality of the heterocyclic triazolate and polytopic phenyl-based carboxylate ligands. The cooperative cocoordination of the metal ions with polytopic triazolyl and carboxylate groups as well as the number/position of the carboxylate group toward the phenyl tether can synergically govern the local connectivity of CuII 4 clusters, CuII 1 cores, and even the overall frameworks. Furthermore, the superexchange coupling interactions in the CuII 4 cluster and between the CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core are quantitatively evaluated. A moderate strong antiferromagnetic coupling up to −206(4) cm–1 was observed in the isolated CuII 4 cluster, which is strongly determined by the specific spatial orientations of double μ3-OH and μ2-triazolyl heterobridges toward the spin carrier.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A structural change from one discrete CuII 4 cluster to two polymeric CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based 3D frameworks with (43⋅52⋅67⋅7⋅82)(53⋅62⋅8)(4⋅52)2 and (44⋅62)2(46⋅64)4(48⋅66⋅8)3 Schläfli notations was achieved by varying the spacer functionality of the heterocyclic triazolate and polytopic phenyl-based carboxylate ligands. The cooperative cocoordination of the metal ions with polytopic triazolyl and carboxylate groups as well as the number/position of the carboxylate group toward the phenyl tether can synergically govern the local connectivity of CuII 4 clusters, CuII 1 cores, and even the overall frameworks. Furthermore, the superexchange coupling interactions in the CuII 4 cluster and between the CuII 4 cluster and CuII 1 core are quantitatively evaluated. A moderate strong antiferromagnetic coupling up to -206(4) cm-1 was observed in the isolated CuII 4 cluster, which is strongly determined by the specific spatial orientations of double μ3-OH and μ2-triazolyl heterobridges toward the spin carrier.

A structural change from a discrete CuII 4 cluster to two alternating CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based three-dimensional frameworks was modulated, exhibiting unusual strong antiferromagnetic coupling up to −206(4) cm−1 within the isolated CuII 4 cluster.

Thermal Analysis and PXRD

TG experiments were carried out to explore the thermal stability of 1–3 (Figure S4 in ). As a result, both 1 and 2 exhibited two obvious weight-loss processes. The first stage was observed between 68 and 124 °C for 1 (obsd. 1.6%, calcd. 2.4%) and between 57 and 95 °C for 2 (calcd. 11.6%, obsd. 10.1%), corresponding to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules. The second one was from 228 to 458 °C for 1 and from 285 to 499 °C for 2, which should be ascribed to the decomposition of the mixed ligands and the collapse of the CuII 4 cluster. In contrast, only one weight-loss stage occurred between 290 and 472 °C for 3, corresponding to the cooperative decomposition of the 3D robust framework. The final residue of the three complexes was all calculated to be CuO (expt. 23.0%, calcd. 21.4% for 1; obsd. 38.3%, calcd. 39.0% for 2; calcd. 38.7%, obsd. 39.5% for 3). The phase purity and structural consistency of the bulk samples of 1–3 have also been evidenced by the comparisons of the experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns (Figure S5 in ).

Magnetic Properties

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on the polycrystalline samples of 1 –3 under an applied direct-current (dc) field of 2 kOe. The χM T value of 1 is 0.55 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K (Figure a) and is much lower than the spin-only value (1.50 cm3 K mol–1) for four magnetically uncoupled CuII ions with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0, suggesting very strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the CuII ions even at room temperature. Upon cooling, the χM T value sharply decreased down to 0.01 cm3 K mol–1 at 75 K and remained almost constant until 2 K. The abrupt increase of the χM below 75 K is due to the presence of paramagnetic impurities. Structurally, due to the presence of a couple of asymmetric μ3-OH bridges within the Cu4 II cluster, three exchange integrals, J 1, J 2, and J 3, are required to quantitatively describe each pairwise superexchange interaction between the adjacent CuII ions (Figure inset). The spin Hamiltonian, H = −2J 1( S 1· S 2 + S 1A· S 2A) – 2J 2 S 1· S 1A – 2J 3( S 1· S 2A + S 1A· S 2), is used to fit the experimental magnetic data of 1, in which S 1, S 2, S 1A, and S 2A are the spin operators of Cu1, Cu2, Cu1A, and Cu2A, respectively. The best-fit parameters obtained by the MAGPACK suite are g = 2.15(1), J 1 = −206(4) cm–1, J 2 = 3.2(3) cm–1, J 3 = −21.4(3) cm–1, and ρ (the percentage of paramagnetic impurity) = 0.015(1), with R = 3.4 × 10–4, where R is the agreement factor defined as Σ­[(χM T)obsd – (χM T)calcd]2/Σ­(χM T)2 obsd.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A structural change from a discrete CuII 4 cluster to two alternating CuII 4 + CuII 1 chain-based three-dimensional frameworks was modulated, exhibiting unusual strong antiferromagnetic coupling up to -206(4) cm-1 within the isolated CuII 4 cluster.

Thermal Analysis and PXRD

TG experiments were carried out to explore the thermal stability of 1-3 (Figure S4 in ). As a result, both 1 and 2 exhibited two obvious weight-loss processes. The first stage was observed between 68 and 124 °C for 1 (obsd. 1.6%, calcd. 2.4%) and between 57 and 95 °C for 2 (calcd. 11.6%, obsd. 10.1%), corresponding to the removal of lattice and coordinated water molecules. The second one was from 228 to 458 °C for 1 and from 285 to 499 °C for 2, which should be ascribed to the decomposition of the mixed ligands and the collapse of the CuII 4 cluster. In contrast, only one weight-loss stage occurred between 290 and 472 °C for 3, corresponding to the cooperative decomposition of the 3D robust framework. The final residue of the three complexes was all calculated to be CuO (expt. 23.0%, calcd. 21.4% for 1; obsd. 38.3%, calcd. 39.0% for 2; calcd. 38.7%, obsd. 39.5% for 3). The phase purity and structural consistency of the bulk samples of 1-3 have also been evidenced by the comparisons of the experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns (Figure S5 in ).

Magnetic Properties

The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibilities were measured on the polycrystalline samples of 1 -3 under an applied direct-current (dc) field of 2 kOe. The χM T value of 1 is 0.55 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K (Figure a) and is much lower than the spin-only value (1.50 cm3 K mol-1) for four magnetically uncoupled CuII ions with S = 1/2 and g = 2.0, suggesting very strong antiferromagnetic couplings between the CuII ions even at room temperature. Upon cooling, the χM T value sharply decreased down to 0.01 cm3 K mol-1 at 75 K and remained almost constant until 2 K. The abrupt increase of the χM below 75 K is due to the presence of paramagnetic impurities. Structurally, due to the presence of a couple of asymmetric μ3-OH bridges within the Cu4 II cluster, three exchange integrals, J 1, J 2, and J 3, are required to quantitatively describe each pairwise superexchange interaction between the adjacent CuII ions (Figure  inset). The spin Hamiltonian,  H  = -2J 1( S  1⋅ S  2 +  S  1A⋅ S  2A) - 2J 2  S  1⋅ S  1A - 2J 3( S  1⋅ S  2A +  S  1A⋅ S  2), is used to fit the experimental magnetic data of 1, in which S 1, S 2, S 1A, and S 2A are the spin operators of Cu1, Cu2, Cu1A, and Cu2A, respectively. The best-fit parameters obtained by the MAGPACK suite are g = 2.15(1), J 1 = -206(4) cm-1, J 2 = 3.2(3) cm-1, J 3 = -21.4(3) cm-1, and ρ (the percentage of paramagnetic impurity) = 0.015(1), with R = 3.4 × 10-4, where R is the agreement factor defined as Σ[(χM T)obsd - (χM T)calcd]2/Σ(χM T)2 obsd.
